questions.question: A young male patient presented with recurrent episodes of acute neurologic dysfunction, cognitive changes, muscle weakness, and lactic acidosis. There is a family history of similar conditions depicted in the pedigree chart below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the most likely diagnosis of a 5-year-old child with hyperphagia, delayed milestones, and growth retardation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Prader-Willi syndrome Explanation: Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) affects the SNORP gene on chromosome 15q. PWS is due to paternal deletion and maternal imprinting of the given gene. Subset of PWS can also occur due to maternal disomy Clinical features: Mental retardation Short stature Hypotonia Obesity (due to increase levels of ghrelin) Obesity, almond shape eyes, down-turned mouth and straight borders of inner legs, Straight borders of ulnar side of hands and scares from skin picking, Active and healing skin lesions on scalp Angelman syndrome (Option A) has a similar genetic basis to PWS but is caused by absent maternal expression of 15q11-q13, involving the UBE3A gene, while the paternal allele is imprinted. Clinical manifestations (Mnemonic- SARI ) S eizure A taxia Mental R etardation I nappropriate laughter (These patients are called happy puppets) Fragile X syndrome (Option C) is an X-linked dominant disorder characterized by classic phenotypic features (tall, long, narrow face with prominent jaw and forehead, large ears, deep-set eyes, macroorchidism).

questions.question: Which of the following does not show the same pattern of inheritance as Leber hereditary optic neuropathy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Fragile-X syndrome Explanation: Fragile-X syndrome shows X-linked Recessive > X-linked dominant inheritance. Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is characterized by permanent loss of vision in young men due to progressive, bilateral optic neuropathy. LHON demonstrates mitochondrial inheritance. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited solely maternally. Thus, females with causative mtDNA may transmit the disease to all offspring. However, the disease's expression is variable due to heteroplasmy (the combination of both mutant and wild DNA in offspring). Mitochondrial diseases thus affect organs with prominent aerobic metabolism. Skeletal muscle (myopathy) and nervous system involvement are common. Some other examples are: Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)/ Kearns-Sayre syndrome (KSS) Leigh syndrome Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS) Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers (MERRF) Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) Primary coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) deficiency Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/mitochondrial-myopathies-clinical-features-and-diagnosis

questions.question: Match the following Disease Trinucleotide repeats a. Fragile X syndrome 1. CAG CGG
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1 Explanation: The below-mentioned disorders are trinucleotide repeat disorders where there is excessive repetition of trinucleotides. In Introns/ Non coding region: Fragile X syndrome - CGG Friedreich ataxia - GAA Myotonic dystrophy -CTG In Exons/ Coding region: Huntington's disease - CAG (Mnemonic- Hunter in a Cage) Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of diseases, 10th Edition, Page 174

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with brief, abrupt, involuntary movements of his arms and face for the last 2 months. A history of Huntington's disease in his father, who was diagnosed at 40 years of age and passed away at the age of 50, is found. What is the mechanism behind this patient’s earlier presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Anticipation Explanation: The given case scenario describes a young male with Huntington’s disease who has manifested the disease at a younger age than his father. HD is a trinucleotide repeat disorder (CAG) that is characterized by psychiatric disturbances and choreoathetosis early on, with cognitive disturbance and death later. HD is characterized by anticipation. Anticipation refers to the phenomenon whereby a genetic disease manifests earlier and is more severe in subsequent generations. It is typically seen in trinucleotide repeat disorders due to increased trinucleotide repeats in the genome of subsequent generations. Examples of diseases showing anticipation include: Autosomal Dominant Autosomal Recessive Multiple spinocerebellar ataxias Huntington’s disease – CAG repeats Myotonic dystrophy – CTG Congenital dyskeratosis – TTAGGG (telomere repeating sequence) Friedreich’s ataxia – GAA X-linked Fragile X Syndrome – CGG Others Crohn’s disease Behcet’s disease Mosaicism (Option B) refers to the presence of two genetically different cell lines in the same individual, which results in variable phenotypic expression. An example is Turner syndrome. Imprinting (Option C) refers to a phenomenon where one copy of the gene is silenced via epigenetic mechanisms (e.g., methylation), and the other copy is expressed. Examples are Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes. Non-penetrance (Option D) - This is a scenario where the patient has a disease-causing mutation but does not have the phenotype or disease. An example is a BRCA1 mutation-positive female who never develops breast or ovarian cancer. Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/huntington-disease-clinical-features-and-diagnosis

questions.question: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician’s office for evaluation of developmental delay and seizures. She is very jovial, has microcephaly and is diagnosed with happy puppet syndrome. What is the genetic basis for this child’s diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Imprinting Explanation: The given clinical scenario likely describes Angelman syndrome. Angelman syndrome (AS) and Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) are examples of genetic imprinting, a phenomenon where one copy of the gene is silenced via epigenetic mechanisms (typically methylation) while the other is deleted/ mutated. In AS, the paternal 15q11-q13 region is imprinted, while the maternal region is deleted/ mutated. In PWS, the opposite is true. Implicated genes in UBE3 in AS and SNORP in PWS. Robertsonian translocation (Option B) is characterized by the amplification of a sequence of three nucleotides. This refers to the fusion of the long arms of two acrocentric chromosomes. Unbalanced translocation can result in the loss of genetic material, causing diseases like Down syndrome and Patau syndrome. Trinucleotide repeats (Option C) is characterized by the amplification of a sequence of three nucleotides. This refer to an excessive and unstable number of trinucleotide copies, which may cause diseases like HD, FXS, etc. Monosomy (Option D) This refers to the loss of one chromosome from a pair. One prominent example is Turner’s syndrome (46XO). Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Page 178.

questions.question: Which of the following explains a single mutant gene leading to different end effects in sickle cell anemia?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Pleiotropy Explanation: A single mutant gene leading to many end effects is called pleiotropism , whereas mutations at several genetic loci producing a similar phenotypic effect are called genetic heterogeneity. Sickle cell anemia is an example of pleiotropy with a single gene mutation causing multiple physical effects. The mutation produces hemoglobin S (HbS) , which makes red blood cells prone to hemolysis. Additionally, it can lead to complications like splenic fibrosis, organ infarcts, and bone pains. All these diverse effects on different organs stem from the initial issue of HbS production. Variable penetrance (Option B) refers to a condition where individuals inherit the mutant gene but are phenotypically normal. Variable expressivity (Option A) refers to the phenomenon where individuals with the same genetic mutation display different levels and types of symptoms or traits. For example, with Marfan syndrome, one person might experience primarily skeletal issues while another could have serious cardiovascular problems, but all these are due to a single primary defect i.e. mutation in the gene FBN1 encoding fibrillin-1.

questions.question: A group of researchers studying genetic material noticed the presence of both wild-type and mutated mitochondrial genomes in different mitochondria of the same cells. What does this finding indicate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Heteroplasmy Explanation: The presence of both wild-type and mutated mitochondrial genomes in different mitochondria of the same cell is called heteroplasmy. A minimum number of mutant mtDNAs must be present in a cell to give rise to a disease. This is called the “threshold effect.” Trinucleotide expansion (Option C) is characterized by the amplification of a sequence of three nucleotides. Copy number variation (CNV) (Option A) is a molecular phenomenon in which nuclear genome sequences are repeated, and the number of repeats varies between individuals of the same species. They contribute to human population diversity. Imprinting (Option D) refers to selectively inactivating a gene's maternal or paternal allele, also known as transcriptional silencing. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of diseases, 10th Edition, Pages 1291, 178, 143 DNA copy number variation: Main characteristics, evolutionary significance, and pathological aspects - PMC (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presents with intentional tremors, cerebellar ataxia, and intellectual disability. His father had similar symptoms at 60 and died due to aortic dissection. The patient's son started showing tremors and has an intellectual disability and aggressive behavior. Additionally males of the family have large ears and mandibles. What condition is most likely affecting him?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Fragile X syndrome Explanation: Fragile X Syndrome (FXS) is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males and the second most common cause overall after Down syndrome. It results from a trinucleotide expansion mutation in the FMR1 gene. The FMR1 gene on the X chromosome contains CGG repeats. In FXS, these repeats amplify, leading to a full mutation (200-4000 repeats) in affected individuals. Fragile X–-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome: A progressive neurodegenerative syndrome affecting carrier males, occurs when CGG repeat is between 55-200. Fragile X-associated primary ovarian failure: Premature ovarian failure in carrier females, leading to menstrual irregularities and decreased fertility Intellectual disability: IQ = 20-40 Physical phenotype: Includes a long face with a large mandible, large ears, and macroorchidism (enlarged testicles). Neurological and neuropsychiatric manifestations: Epilepsy, aggressive behavior, autism spectrum disorder, anxiety disorder, and hyperactivity. PCR-based detection of CGG repeats is the method of choice for diagnosis, replacing cytogenetic methods. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of diseases, 10th Edition, Pages 174, 176

questions.question: A one-month-old infant presents with developmental delays and physical features such as a prominent occiput, low-set ears, clenched hands with overlapping fingers, and a small mouth with a protruding tongue. Heart murmurs and rocker-bottom foot deformity are also noted. Which syndrome is the most likely cause of these features?
questions.explanation: extra copy of chromosome 18- Trisomy 18. Features: Low birth weight Closed fists with overlapping fingers Rocker-bottom feet Microcephaly Micrognathia Cardiac and renal malformations Mental retardation 95% of cases die in the 1st year of life Noonan syndrome (Option A) is associated with mutations in the PTPN11 gene and typically presents with characteristic facial features, congenital heart defects, and short stature. (Male counterpart of Turner's syndrome)-Noonan syndrome differs from Turner syndrome by having decreased IQ (normal in Turner) and normal fertility (decreased in Turner). Down syndrome results from Trisomy 21 (Option B) and is characterized by intellectual disability, characteristic facial features, and various congenital anomalies. Patau syndrome , or Trisomy 13 (Option C) , is associated with multiple physical abnormalities such as cleft lip and palate, congenital heart defects, and severe intellectual disability.

questions.question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for delayed milestones. Upon examination, the pediatrician notices several physical features, including upward-slanting eyes, a flat facial profile, a protruding tongue, and a single palmar crease. Which type of inheritance is definitely not present in this child?
questions.explanation: diagnosis of Down syndrome. The modes of inheritance of Down syndrome are as follows: Meiotic Nondisjunction of chromosome 21 (95%) (Option A): This is associated with advanced maternal age. In most cases, the nondisjunction occurs in the Ovum. Robertsonian Translocation (4%) (Option B): This is not associated with the mother's age. Translocation occurs via the long arm of other acrocentric chromosomes, like Chr. 22/14. There is some degree of familial inheritance in such translocations. Mitotic Nondisjunction (1%) (Option C ): This leads to mosaicism, in which few of the cells are triploid, and few are normal. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological Basis of Diseases, 10th Edition, Pages 166,167.

questions.question: A 6-month-old child has recently passed away after a long ICU stay. Examination reveals microphthalmia and microcephaly. Other known diagnoses included ventricular septal defect, polycystic kidney disease, and omphalocele at birth. What is the chromosome involved?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Chromosome 13 Explanation: The given scenario describes Patau syndrome or Trisomy 13. Clinical features and associations include Rocker-bottom feet Severe intellectual disability Keyhole/ Coloboma (eyes) Microphthalmia, microcephaly, holoprosencephaly Cleft lip/palate Polydactyly Congenital heart disease Renal defects-Polycystic kidney disease Umbilical hernia,Omphalocele Defects occur due to impaired mesoderm fusion in the midline. Affected children usually pass away before one year of age. Screening may establish prenatal diagnosis - low hCG, PAPP-A in 1st trimester. Trisomy 21 is Down syndrome . Patients can live well into adulthood. (Option A) Trisomy 18 is Edward syndrome . Similar to PS, patients typically pass away early in life. Clinical features include prominent occiput, rocker-bottom feet, intellectual disability, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, low-set ears, micrognathia (small jaw), omphalocele, and myelomeningocele. (Option B) XYY syndrome (Jacobs syndrome) is a rare, sporadically inherited disorder. Features include intellectual disability and tall stature. (Option D) Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/congenital-cytogenetic-abnormalities

questions.question: A 30-year-old tall male patient presents to the clinic for fertility treatment. He undergoes testing and is found to have low sperm counts. He has a history of diabetes, and a physical examination reveals gynecomastia, small testes, and minimal facial and body hair. What chromosomal abnormality is most likely causing this condition in the patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 47,XXY Explanation: Based on the above clinical scenario, the patient can be diagnosed with Klinefelter syndrome. Klinefelter syndrome is male hypogonadism resulting from two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y chromosomes. Karyotype: The most common is 47, XXY, from meiotic nondisjunction; some have mosaic patterns (e.g., 46, XY/47, XXY). X chromosome genes: Some genes escape inactivation, leading to uneven dosage compensation and overexpression. 45, X (Turner syndrome) (Option A) : In females, one X chromosome is absent, leading to short stature. 47, XXX (Option C) : Triple X syndrome in females, characterized by tall stature and potential learning or behavioral issues. 47, XYY (Option D) : XYY syndrome in males, associated with tall stature but typically without significant physical features of hypogonadism.

questions.question: An 18-year-old girl presents to the clinic due to the concern that she hasn't started menstruating yet. The girl has a short stature and a webbed neck. Physical examination reveals a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Turner syndrome Explanation: Turner syndrome is characterized by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, leading to hypogonadism in phenotypic females. The image below shows karyotyping in Turner syndrome. Mullerian agenesis (Option B) is a condition where the uterus and upper part of the vagina are underdeveloped or absent, leading to primary amenorrhea. It does not typically include the physical features seen in Turner syndrome. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (Option C) can cause primary amenorrhea but is not associated with the physical features seen in Turner syndrome. 47, XXX syndrome (Option D) may lead to tall stature but is not typically associated with the specific physical features and primary amenorrhea seen in Turner syndrome.

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with tall stature and long limbs, along with a history of frequent joint dislocations. Upon physical examination, he exhibits long fingers ,sunken chest, and an echocardiogram shows a dilated aortic root. Considering these clinical features, which of the following genes are commonly mutated in this condition?
questions.explanation: Gene on chromosome 15 Revised Ghent's Criteria: 1. Family history (Autosomal Dominant) 2. Clinical features 3. Fibrillin 1 Gene analysis. Clinical Features: Marfan D isease The most common Clinical Manifestation is Skeletal Abnormalities. M itral Valve Prolapse (Most common Cardiac abnormality) A ortic Dissection (Most common cause of death) R etinal Detachment (eye problem) F reely moveable Joint (most common Thumb joint) A rachnodactyly (long fingers, spider fingers), High A rched Palate N ine Feet Tall, Pigeon chest (defect in sternum) D islocation of the lens (Ectopia Lentis- Direction of dislocation is Supero Temporal) Steinberg Sign - Positive if the thumb tip extends beyond the palm when folded into a closed fist Walker Sign- Positive if the thumb and fifth finger overlap when you grip your wrist with the opposite hand Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathological Basis of diseases, 10th Edition, Page 148, 149
